column4: Does nayone know how I can burn a CD on the same drive that I'm running a LiveCD on ?
anyone have a tip on how to recursively delete hidden dirs?  (without wiping the entire drive)
find . -name \.\* | xargs rm -rf
dangerous!
ouch,.. that's the easiest way that you know of ?
what's difficult about the command I suggested?
it's not actually difficult, it just seems a bit tedious for a simple operation,
let me poke at it for a moment and see if there's anything questionable
try 'find . -name \.\* | xargs ls' for playing
is this going to run   rm -rf     on every file in every subdirectory, or just the dirs ?
it's not really so bad, it just looked a bit long for something simple
'find . -type d -name \.\*' will find only directories beginning with a dot
wait isn't that going to match .. too, leaving me in the same position as if i just rm -rf .* (!!!!!)
strange -- it seems to match . but not ..
still, that is a problem!
can you reproduce that behaviour, though?
what are you referring to?  it seems to match . but not .. , every single time
thanks, that's what I wanted to hear
I suppose it's intentional, to prevent find from crawling endlessly,

but it really does expose a filesystem flaw with the . and .. shared with the hidden directory bit,.. personally, i think there should be a sort of hidden flag that is not a part of the filename, which could be referenced by a character or some new key, right ?
I think your argument is valid. The thing about conventions, though, is that once they are 20 or 30 years old, it'll need more than a convincing argument to change them...
right,... but whoever is writing the next great operating system , will make sure to change this we hope :)

I'm pretty certain that I will stick with unix. Although I am sometimes attracted by interface concepts like Aqua or Symphony OS, there is rarely a reason to change the underlying system. I'll stop offtopic now, sorry
